documents.title: Robert Burton Patent - 1300 acres (formerly Edward Hatcher's deserted land)
documents.location_description: on N. side of James River, beginning at Lilly Valley, to Cole's run, nigh Cornelius Creek, over Mr. Beauchampt's path
documents.transcription_excerpt: 6 JUNE 1699: Robert Burton, 1300 acs. Henrico Co., on N. side of James Riv., 6 June 1699. p. 187. Beg. at Lilly Valley, to Cole's run, nigh Cornelius Cr., over Mr. Beauchampt's path, &c. Granted Edward Hatcher 6 Oct. 1675, deserted, & now granted by order, &c. Imp. of 26 pers.

people.reasoning: Robert Burton Sr. receiving Edward Hatcher's deserted 1675 patent
Original 1675 patentee who deserted the land

documents.notes: CRITICAL: This patent transfers Edward Hatcher's 1675 land to Robert Burton. This is the same area where Michael Johnson later patents land (1714-1717). The survey was 'identically described in both patents' per Tony's notes. Robert Burton was granted this by General Court order 5 October 1698.

documents.title: Robert Burton Sr. Patent - 300 acres Cornelius Creek
documents.location_description: in the parish of Varina and on the east side of Cornelius Creek, by Parker's path
documents.transcription_excerpt: On April 25, 1701, there was a grant to 'Robert Burton, Senior,' of 300 acres in Henrico:- 'in the parish of Varina and on the east side of Cornelius Creek by Parker's path due for the transportation of six persons.' At that time (1701) the landowners adjoining Robert Burton were John Pleasants, John Davis and William Ballew.
documents.notes: This additional 300 acres is near the 1300 acre tract. The 'Senior' designation confirms there was also a Robert Burton Jr. by this date.

documents.title: Robert Burton Land Acknowledgments
documents.transcription_excerpt: Robert [Burton] did not hold all of his patented land; in 1700, May 1st, he and Mary his wife acknowledged a conveyance of 300 acres to Richard Cox; 150 acres to Wm. Hobson, and 200 (300)? to Nicholas Perkins. (Henrico Orders 1694-1701, p. 264).

people.reasoning: Same William Hobson from 1704 Woodson agreement

documents.notes: Shows Robert Burton selling portions of his land in 1700. The deed to Hobson specifies it was 'part of a patent granted unto the said Robert Burton for 1300 acres as lapsed land June 6, 1699, small branch of Cornelius Creek, quarter fields.'

documents.title: St. Peters Parish Vestry Book - Michael Johnson and John Jones at Edloe Plantation
documents.transcription_excerpt: 27 February 1702/3, O. S., p. 55 [renumbered p. 57; Chamberlayne, p. 89] Peter masse upon his motion to this vestrey is ordered to his tithables the tithables on Mr Edloes plantation John Jones and Michaell Johnson

people.reasoning: John Jones listed with Michael Johnson - Tony identifies as brother-in-law
Michael Johnson - White Oak DNA anchor. This is his FIRST documented appearance.

people.notes: John Edloe or Matthew Edloe - the Edloe Plantation

documents.notes: CRITICAL DOCUMENT: This is the EARLIEST documented record of Michael Johnson. Tony notes 'Michael Johnson in 1698 was living by Beaverdam Swamp' - but the 1702 vestry entry is the first PRIMARY SOURCE. Tony interprets this as showing Michael Johnson moved to the Edloe Plantation tithes from St. Peters Parish lands in New Kent County.

documents.title: Robert Burton Grant - 17 acres
documents.location_description: bounding on the head of the Longfield patent, land of Thomas Taylor, to William Burton's line
documents.transcription_excerpt: On July 15, 1717, he received another grant: 17 acres bounding on the head of the Longfield patent, land of Thomas Taylor, to William Burton's line, thence on his line s.w. by w. 34 to the said Burton's corner pine, thence on the head of the Longfield patent south to the beginning.

key_findings: Robert Burton received Edward Hatcher's deserted 1675 patent in 1699 - this is the land area where Michael Johnson later patents
Michael Johnson's FIRST documented appearance is the St. Peters Parish vestry entry dated 27 February 1702/3
Tony's claim of Michael Johnson at Beaverdam Swamp in 1698 is NOT verified by primary source in this file
William Burton (adjacent to Michael Johnson in 1714) is stated by Tony to be son of Robert Burton Sr. - not yet confirmed
Hutchins Burton (1694-1763) appointed road surveyor to Tuckahoe Bridge in 1719 - same area as Michael Johnson
The Burton family effectively inherited the Hatcher land network that surrounded Michael Johnson
